comments.commentBody: Let's not be so quick to blame Mr. Obama for the current policy. Yes, NCLB needs to be radically changed, if not completely done away with. But the current President didn't put the law in place, his predecessor did, and I can tell you as a teacher, it is a miserable law.

pls don't make the science fair another piece of the corporatocracy. let the kids learn as much about science as they can, make it real for them, and then stand back and let them show us how it's done. science is the coolest thing ever and the kids know it.

It is heartening to hear that so many American students are going above and beyond the required work for their courses by participating in such contests.

I question, however, the teachers who are 'burdened' by state requirements to explain such simple things as the 'parts of a cell.' Evidently, these weighty topics prevent them from devoting class time to research projects. Isn't this kind of scientific knowledge basic? I suppose there really is a huge gap between the worst and best high school science programs in our country...

Of course, this teach-to-the-test policy didn't start with Obama, it got its biggest push from the G.W.Bush sponsored, and badly misnamed, No Child Left Behind Act. But it's true that Obama is continuing this destructive policy.

The national testing and national standards movements are terrible diversions of scarce time, talent, and money from the real problems of education. And the interference of Utopian economists, self-centered businessmen, and ignorant politicians in our school systems creates further disaster.

Check out susanohanian.org or Diane Ravitch's latest book for better commentary than I can provide.

The idea that there exists a "broad swath" of young people who have the intelligence and, most importantly, the *raw quantitative ability* to "do science" is almost unimaginably absurd.

There are *very* few people who can contribute real and lasting work in the hard, quantitative sciences. And these are an almost entirely male group: men are profoundly over-represented on that end of the bell-curve where it counts, and the ability to do elite-level mathematics, theoretical physics, *hard* computer science and serious, quantified engineering disciplines is an ability shared, in any case, by vanishingly few men.

Weak, ill-quantified "soft" sciences -- which are little more than make-work "disciplines" to find tasks for our ludicrously bloated crew of "credentialled" graduates -- are an utter waste of time and energy. Google the recent "arsenic life forms" atrocity for the most perfect possible example. These science fairs are nothing but window-dressing.

It's high time this *equalist fantasia* fell from view: it needs to be replaced by a hard-minded emphasis on *reality.* A big part of that reality is recognizing innate and hard-wired differences between our cognitive elite, almost entirely male, and all the rest. Let's have no more special pleading.

Obama is going to blame China again.

Actually, the Academy of Science-St. Louis Science Fair, now co-sponsored by MEMC Electronics and Monsanto, is on the rise!  More than 250 schools and we're holding the 50% increase in Honors Fair students attained in 2010.  The keys are parents who capture the "I wonder" questions their children have and help them turn them into projects; schools that recognize the value of hands-on inquiry; and mentors who remember how they caught the fever for science!

Hmmm...a teacher "logging unpaid hours"?  It's called being an American, dedicated, salaried employee.  It's called doing your job.  If I logged my hours and divided it by my salary I would be getting far below the minimum wage.  Dedicated teachers have low wages, just like the rest of us.  Please.

This is ridiculous. Explain how teaching math concepts cuts into the time a science teacher has to supervise a science fair. They are two different teachers. I am so tired of teachers complaining that they cannot teach the basic competencies without drill baby drill. They cannot squeeze in the slightest deviation from a narrow slice of academics demanded by the state testing. All creativity has been squeezed out of the curriculum. And it is Obama's fault. Right.

And we need the Federal Department of Education for what exactly? Ever since its creation under Jimmy Carter education in this country has declined. The government is the problem right here as it is in so many other instances.

Today one can easily predict why science fairs are left behind. Most politicians, such as Mr. Obama, have liberty arts background and law degrees. They are the most obvious ones get elected. They have absolute no science/engineering knowledge themselves yet they are talking as if they know how important science is.  They are very very good at rah-rah jobs and making empty promises, that will get them elected. This system has served this country well for more than two hundreds years. But right now the US is facing a changing world. This time the same old leadership system can lead us out of this second Sputnik Moment?

My kids experience with science fairs has been less than stellar.  There does not appear to be any standards for judging, or even simply evaluating if its really an experiment or something else.  Teachers believe this is something extra, rather than part of the teaching experience.  Unfortunately, I'll be trying to influence my kids technical education through other means.
Politicians have enough problems doing the few things we ask of them without meddling in education. So many downsides to this without any apparent benefit.

Test, test, test! Not very creative, but vital to the success of the teacher and school. Creativity is one thing that is not tested on standardized tests. Science requires questioning and trying to find the answers. It isn't canned knowledge or skill.

Incidentally, are students in charter schools tested to the same extent as those in public schools? Does the Department of Education have the power to close charter schools for poor performance on tests? What is the record on that?

So take it further back...maybe we need to celebrate K-12 science programs the way we celebrate our K-12 sports teams. Our county has countless extracurricular programs for sports, parents vie to coach and assistant coach, but as the article suggests, the science and technology and creative programs like Odyssey of the Mind are begging for teachers and parents to put in the extra time.

But changing the culture isn't a matter of wishful thinking or bright visions. If we depend solely on parents for encouragement and support, we will lose many bright people who won't fight the double whammy of disinterest from home and from society. If the national and educational vision truly is to support these disciplines, the message has to be loud, consistent, and backed with the money and time and rewards.

to paraphrase the poster/button/T-shirt saying...what if the science club had all the funding it needed, and the football team had to hold a bake sale to fund their equipment?

While the teachers, I feel, may have a point about the education policy, blaming the President, is the wrong person.

This is the responsibility of PARENTS. From the voting standpoint, in which parents voted(seemingly) against their own interests, and that of their children(or more likely, against the children of their neighbors if they don't have any--"cut property taxes because I don't have kids", sound familiar?)

The problem with Parental Units, is many fold, but, some of the major culprits:working two jobs, caring for more than one child, caring for a disabled child; flat out disinterest...the kind that comes from not getting a decent education at least to recognize that its important to have one in the first place. One that recognizes you don't necessarily go to college to get a better job, though that can be a benefit. You go to college to get educated.

So, before teachers fall into the trap set for them by neo-cons, cons and GOP'ers, to attack Obama in a desperate grab for unity, let them stop and think first...what forced President Obama to accept such a policy?

One, the economic climate was not one in which he had the luxury of fighting tooth and nail for every 'right' thing to be done...he had to compromise, and compromise quick...or did everyone forget he took the oath of office while the drapes were still on fire? Secondly, the political climate was set to take advantage of the economic climate...GOP'ers, knowing that President Obama didn't have the time to 'fight tooth and nail' with out risk of getting 'nothing' done, pressed against him on every issue. Not to mention that he never really had a 'true' majority. Sure, he had a majority of Democrats in number, but many of those Democrats parrot the same tired and proven false talking points(which will no doubt be used to bash my comment at some point) that came from the GOP; which is fine, everyone's entitled to their opinion, even if they're wrong. Its not their fault...they're just 'doing their jobs'. Its the electorate's fault. They voted in these nattering-naybobs of negativity BEFORE President Obama took office. Then, because they cut any progress at all(smaller stimulus package, threats to education, removal of the public option from HCR), but "sold" themselves as Democrats, the public, lacking the will to actually investigate...lacking the understanding that if you elect someone, and they don't follow the path you wanted them to, you either gather your neighbors together(as we did in Delray Beach to fend of the 'red tide' of Walmart) and petition for removal, or bide your time and elect someone who will seek to achieve the agenda you want.

Finally, because most Americans don't know how their system works, or, believe, falsely, that the system doesn't work for them(false, because it wasn't intended to work 'just for them', its to work for all of us, which requires we all find ground to compromise, and on that ground will we find the representatives who'll best achieve what we feel the nation needs), they also don't know how to set an agenda for themselves, let alone outline one they think would be best for the nation.

Now some may say, isn't that the job of the representative/senator...to reach out to their constituents, tell them what they need to know? Educate them one what that agenda should be? Well, yes and no...and for the most part, no. Yes, they should, but if relied on TOO long, as we've seen in the last 2 decades, this spawns a class of selfish, ignorant voters who 'expect' everything to go their way...because they aren't filtering the info, they're getting info by proxy...their congresspeople. And when their only told what they want to hear, while the gears on the rack are cranked ever tighter, they seem to ignore the pain after awhile.

If they'd learn about the issues, or at least be as up to date on them so they could tell if their congresspeople are out of touch with the issues, then, things would be different.

Wrap all that together into one human being...and you've got something that looks like an educated voter.

Which, of course, means nothing if that educated voter stays home.

Sciences, arts, creativity, critical thinking are being sacrificed at the altar of proficiency testing. Underlying those destructive trends is the business "accountability" model initiated by Bush's 'no child' and continued by Obama. A new 'sputnik- generation' of creative problem solvers will remain a pipe-dream. If anything, the efficiency driven Bush-Obama education machine will spit a generation of technically skilled but mindless robots. And that's what our corporatist state needs most, pliant robots rather than 'creative troublemakers'.

Science research projects, at any level, are what true science is all about. This is where students, at all levels, go beyond rote book learning, to asking themselves questions and searching for reliable answers. This is the process of science. Before you can discover the answer to a question you might pose, one must search out what others have already asked and discovered. Enormous time is required to do this and evaluate the information, long before one finally arrives back at the original question asked. Usually one finds that others have already asked, and possibly answered, the original question. But in just this process, one learns infinitely more than simply reading information out of books.

Moreover, one always ends up going far beyond the original question in reading and discovering what others have done and seeking to evaluate the quality of what they have done.

Most high school environments are not set up to accomplish such tasks at all. The teachers there are already way overburdened as it is.

The system of teaching science must receive major surgery if we are to compete with some other serious countries today. For example, we are all bombarded with repeated, over and over and over again, results of relatively trivial sports entertainment propaganda at every broadcast, radio, television, newspaper, etc., but nothing about science and mathematics. How about a little equal time? There are more significant and enlightening areas of human endeavor than just sports entertainment all day long, sex and violence from the Hollywood Perverts.
We spend far too much time on memorizing the names of things or diseases, or objects or concepts, rather than time developing the thought processes of induction and deduction and the conceptual mental pictures or images or models which lead to our mental picture of our world from the infinitely small to the infinitely large, from the infinite past to the infinite future. Concepts of what is space and what is time? What is an electron for example? What is a proton or a neutron? What is an hydrogen atom? What is cancer? What is a living cell? Etc., etc., etc.
One can memorize the name of a bird in 4 or 8 or 100 languages, but in the end one learns from this effort nothing about how a bird flies or obtains food or reproduces or cleans itself or makes a nest etc. We spend far too much effort on rote memorization of names, rather than developing the critical mental processes for analysis and synthesis to, hopefully, reach beyond what others have placed before us, and move to a new direction and new knowledge. Very few ideas are really new and most have been already discovered by others perhaps decades or centuries ago. Even experienced scholars often do not properly give credit to others. Young students must be taught to strictly comply with the rules of science and the scientific method, of honestly giving credit to others who have already made discoveries, and honestly reporting all facts of experiments, and honestly reporting all possible problems with experiments or various interpretations of them. All pro and all con must be presented, not just one sided advertisements.
The great physicist Richard Feynman emphasizes this in his various writings. One must not fool
others, but most importantly, one must not fool oneself. It is easiest to fool oneself.
Mathematical thought processes are essential for science, but one almost never proves any scientific principle with the usual inductive or deductive mathematical proof. The proof that scientists use is the one scoffed at by mathematicians; namely, the proof by example. The first thing one learns in mathematics is that no finite number of examples can prove a general theorem. But one counter example can disprove a general theorem. But in science the only true way or "proof" is by example. One considers certain laws "proved", like Newton's Law of Gravitation or Coulomb's electrical force law or Kepler's laws of planetary motion because they have been shown to agree with experiments over and over and over again without exception. Then we regard them as "proved". Of course in a pure mathematical sense they still remain to be proved.
Science is really nothing more than what can be reproduced by others experimentally and nothing more. One must be very careful reading too much and implying too much and extrapolating too far from concepts and pictures and models, because one can be very misled by false assumptions. In science on must constantly check one's premises and assumptions. Assumptions can be very dangerous especially when one forgets they were made in the first place.
Students never learn all this from books and rarely from others. They learn by doing and that is what science fairs and individual research are all about. We owe a debt to the many dedicated teachers who spend time with students while others may be more highly rewarded for less.
Winfield J. Abbe, Ph.D., Physics

I honestly think more and more regular Main St  'are' waking to what's going on, and that it's not a question of 'will' they respond, but what form that response will take. As they watch the current government 'not' represent the best interests of the majority of citizens, deliberately make choices that place us in harms way all over again in order to curry favor with Wall St and mega corporations, anger has become a palitable thing. It is going to reach a boiling point here-maybe not as quickly as it would some places, but you can't keep squeezing more and more from the bottom and middle to please those on high and not have a price to pay. How many times do you think the American public can watch the wealthy and powerful be rewarded-no matter what damage they do, or to how many-see their own meager savings wiped out, not find jobs, be battered over and over by price increases and new 'fees' and taxes,and insult to injury...have the rich and powerful saying 'we' caused it all..? How long before we quit asking and start physically 'taking' a fairer share of things. Insist on some real reform by whatever means it takes? When people are backed against a wall like this, see all we worked for disappearing into already bloated pockets, things getting worse and worse, and 'justice and fairness' so perverted that no one is even pretending to stop those who are doing it, we 'do' fight back. We have in the past.  When it happens, we will be fighting for our lives and futures..and there are way more of 'us, than 'them'.

I have a friend who is one of 8 children. Grace at her house consisted of, "Father, Son, and Holy Ghost, who eats the fastest gets the most."

Namaste, Gaia
Namaste Earth and waters,
forest, redwoods, and Flora
Namaste mountain, sky, sun, fog, and Luna

Namaste people and creatures,
our friends the corvos*,
our home GB,
*I say* and (husband's name) Most Beloved,
*he replies* and (my name) my very dearest.

May our hearts minds and eyes
remain open to the beauty and wonder
of the world around us today.

May the Bodhisattvas help us feel compassion
for all sentient beings, especially
ourselves, each other, and our families.

And may the guardian deities guide us, guard us, and protect us
and help us make the most of today.

* corvo is our name for the local population which requires particular patience in this location.

The Namaste is just a general salute to the sacred in the world around us. Calling on the Bodhisattvas and Guardian Deities is sort of figurative, not a literal belief in these entities. In our lexicon, the big redwoods are Bodhisattvas as well.

it's very centering to go out on the deck in the early morning and acknowledge these things and focus on a good day.

The childhood morning prayer, still applicable:
"Angel of God, my guardian dear,
To whom God's love commits me here,
Ever this day be at my side
To light and guard, to rule and guide."

at night, I change the last two lines to:
"Ever this night be at my side
To watch and ward, my dreams to guide."
